fields.description:
Here is an example script that I would like to produce that would use the Remote API (with changes in bold):
# Run a build - executeBuild works for this
# Get the build number for the build - *executeBuild needs to return the build number*
# Wait for the build to complete - *need new API to call to do this* or one that can be put in a polling loop to check on status of this particular build (by build number)*
# Get the build results for the build I submitted - *need to have an API like getLatestBuildResults but that works by providing the build number and key*
# Add a label to the build results - *new API to add a label a specific build result*

My suggestion would be to change getLatestBuildResults to getBuildResults that allows for the build number as input and defaults to being the latest
fields.summary: Remote API additions

fields.description:
Having a space in Bamboo builder label fails builds in Bamboo.

Builds in Bamboo fail with: 

"Cannot build "Tes2 - Defad" as the build is not using an "Maven 2.0" builder with an unknown label "Maven 2.0". You need to add a new builder or change the build's builder (Occurrences 38)"
fields.summary: When adding builders - adding a label with space in the beginning of fails to build

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo will do an initial build of a project once its created.

It should not perform the initial build when using the manual build strategy.

A possible solution might be to give user the option of performing an initial build when configuring the plan?

Originally a forum issue (See, http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257247768#257247768)
fields.summary: Bamboo should not automatically build project after the (first) initial checkout on a manual build plan

fields.description: Done - Edwin is checking
fields.summary: incorporate parts of Installation Guide into Upgrade Guide

fields.description: Dependant child builds don't seem to trigger if the source root was changed for the child builds.  This may be due to the fact that they are configured as Manual builds which may not trigger a clean checkout and build of the new source tree.  This can be seen for the Professional and Standard Branch builds on JBAC.
fields.summary: Dependent builds don't trigger after changing source branch

fields.description: Cron triggers of the form '0 0 14,20 * * ?' don't seem to work at the moment.  They get returned by the UI as [[0 0 14, 20 * * ?]] and don't seem to trigger at all.  (See the JDK1.4 and JDK1.5 builds on jbac for an example).
fields.summary: Cron triggers that specify multiples (entries with commas) get interpreted as arrays of Strings

fields.description: In Bamboo 1.1 you are able to pass meta-data into your build.  We have changed our build to use the build number passed in from bamboo to create a label in perforce which is a big improvement over how we had to do it previously.  Is there also meta-data that we can use to get the last build that passed?  We have a clover build that runs nightly and we want to make sure it is running against a code that has already passed and it would be very useful for us to be able to pass in the last build that passed.  Also is there documentation anywhere that says what meta-data is available to pass into your build?
fields.summary: Add a meta-data, to indicate last past build for a given plan.

fields.description: It would be nice if there was a setting that would pause the build for a set period of time after a build completes.  This would give the build a little down time before it checked for new changes and would also allow developers time to see if the build passed before checking in more changes.
fields.summary: Pause in between builds

fields.summary: Upgrade SVNKit to the latest version

fields.description:
When a user qualifies for multiple rules for sending notifications, they receive multiple notifications.  So for example, on the Spring commit triggered builds, our notification rules are as follows:

Commiters: All Completed Builds
Project Lead Group: Failed and First Successful Build

So now, if I'm an both a project lead and the person who committed a change, I get the exact same email twice.  I should only get it once even though I qualify for both rules.
fields.summary: Duplicate Email Notifications

fields.description:
Given Subversion commits are atomic, it would be great if there was one Bamboo build run per commit.

At the moment, the project is put in the queue when a trigger is received, and when the build starts, it runs 'svn update', getting all changes up to HEAD. On a busy server, where a build might take half an hour to progress through the queue, this can mean three or four commits are bundled together in the same build.

The benefits of having a single build per commit is that it is easier to see exactly which commit broke the build.

In terms of implementation, Bamboo needs to record the revision number which triggered the build in its queue item. When that queue item is to be executed, Bamboo needs to update to that revision number, and run the build. If subsequent triggers come from the Subversion system while the first one is still queued, they must be put in the queue separately with their associated revision number.

Note: this is the opposite of BAM-926. I'm not sure exactly why those guys want Bamboo to collapse multiple atomic commits into one build. That seems illogical to me.
fields.summary: One build per Subversion commit

fields.summary: Error after i have upgraded ldap in Bamboo

fields.description:
The current create plan wizard could be improved.  

* It may take time to get valid configuration details during which the session may time out and all data is lost

Possible Solutions
* Break up the creation process into smaller pieces rather than one big long wizard
* Save setup configuration between screens so information is not lost if sessions time out.
* Provide the user with an option to save the configuration to resume at a later time
* Let build configuration be saved even when not valid and just not build until it is valid.
fields.summary: Improvement to ease of use for create plan wizard

fields.description: The remove plans screen have the plans in randometical order
fields.summary: Ordering of the remove plans screen

fields.description:
See

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/3.2.2+Triggering+a+Build+on+Code+Check-in

"For CVS, this is done by editing some files in the CVSROOT module." is not particularly helpful information...
fields.summary: Improve the CVS trigger doco

fields.description:
Currently, environment variables may be set per plan.
For environments with a large number of plans, it would be handy to be able to define environment variables globally for a particular builder or globally.

Users, should be given option to set user environment levels per builder or globally.

Example:  My maven is running out of memory, and requires the environment variable 
MAVEN_OPTS="-Xms512m -Xmx1024m -XX:MaxPermSize=512m" 
to be set.
I would like to be able to set this to a reasonable level for anything built with maven, but don't want to edit 120 plans to do this.

The problem is Bamboo will pick up JAVA_OPTS from command line and pass it down to the build: we should be able to override JAVA_OPTS or any other variable at a global or per builder level.
fields.summary: Builder and Global level environment variables

fields.description:
On the dashboard, clicking on a link to a user that doesn't exist in bamboo in the "Updated By:" text navigates to a 404 page.
The same thing happens if you click on the user name in the build results page.
fields.summary: Clicking on a link for a user that doesn't exist results in a 404 error page.

fields.description:
In the tooltip that appears when you hover over a user in the dashboard does not deal with backslashes (\) properly.  It seems to be trying to interpret them as escape sequences.

See the attached screenshot.  In this case, the username in subversion is 5D\tchu but when bamboo tries to display it in the tooltip, it looks like it interpreted the \t to mean a tab.
fields.summary: Backslashes in usernames not displayed correctly on tooltip

fields.description:
Bamboo shows a failed Maven2 build as a successful one. It is probably something to do with how many lines is read from the Maven log to recognise the failed build. Whenever there are some missing dependencies and "cannot resolve symbol" errors, they are shown after "[ERROR] BUILD FAILURE" line and that may cause the incorrect behaviour.

This problem should be easy to reproduce by creating a few objects in Java code but leaving all the necessary dependencies out of pom.xml. 

Notice also that "The build will produce test results." flag must be turned OFF to show off this bug.

When "The build will produce test results." flag is turned on the build fails as it should.

A used Maven command was:
mvn clean install --batch-mode

fields.description:
Builds triggered by dependencies are not reported correctly in email notifications. Instead they are reported as initial or manual builds.

It would be even better if dependency builds indicated which dependency triggered the build.

Originally a Support request - https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-85

Bamboo automatically links issue keys to JIRA. This is done using the arrow icon next to each issue key. Clicking on the issue key actually goes to the "View JIRA issue page" in Bamboo.

We should make sure this distinction more obvious.

fields.description:
Running the "Confluence - Unit test" on JDK 1.4 fails on the Bamboo instance running on Keg. 
It succeeds running it against JDK 1.5.

Running the same tests on the same server, same JDK, same Maven is fine outside of Bamboo...

I ran then using maven debug mode and it seems that with JDK 1.4 configured there are some JDK 1.5 libraries on the classpath which could be the cause of the problem.

fields.description:
Currently Bamboo does not support CVS Alias Modules as bamboo expects there to be a directory with the specified checkout module name.

------------
There is a current workaround using ampersand modules:

The configuration supported by Bamboo requires you to create a module with the same name as the ampersand module (it can be empty) to specify as the root of the ampersand module

eg. 
create a module allbuilds
define an ampersand module 
allbuilds allbuilds &project2 &project2 &project3
fields.summary: Support for CVS Alias Modules

fields.description:
Bamboo needs to return results for all the latest builds for a given project, instead of just a specific plan.

Also it would be good be able to query just what projects are configured for a given Bamboo instance and the details for those projects.
fields.summary: Improve the REST api in Bamboo to allow getting details from Bamboo at the project level instead of the plan/build level.

fields.description:
Ability to Export selected projects 

Originally posed in forum - http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257247499#257247499
"There also doesn't seem to be an option to extract a single project from Bamboo and migrate it to another"
fields.summary: Import Export individual projects / plans

fields.description: The Perforce changelist number is crucial for easily tracing code submissions. Omitting this information greatly diminishes the usefulness of the code changes page and the email build notifications.
fields.summary: Code changes should display Perforce changelist number

fields.description:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=51872599 makes this statement:

It is recommended not to revert back to local user management after implementing LDAP integration with Bamboo. If an LDAP user has commented on builds, or if they have set their 'favourites', then Bamboo might throw an exception due to missing users.

Bamboo MUST be able to deal with deleted users better.  When using an LDAP repository, often we (Bamboo administrators) has no control over when users are removed from the corporate directory controlled by IT.  These are corporate policies when people leave or change their name.
fields.summary: LDAP - deleted user will cause problems

fields.description:
I can't tell you how annoying it is when some IDIOT thinks that it is funny to reset my password (the perils of internet facing bamboo)

The password reset option should email a link that will reset the password when the user visits the url
fields.summary: Password reset should send a link to reset rather than just resetting

fields.summary: logging in as an ldap user causes a db exception
Import fails if the import file is too large

fields.description:
Bamboo did not handle the case where there was a local user defined with the same id as an LDAP user. 

This should also be fixed. Jira and Confluence both handle this case correctly.

This issue was discussed in BAM-1199
fields.summary: Bamboo will fail to integrate with LDAP if the users on LDAP and Bamboo have the same user names

fields.description:
It'd be good to be able to only export parts of Bamboo. Such as:
 # Export only configurations
 # Export only build results (no artifacts)
 # Export with no users
 # Export selected projects

Originally posed in forum - [http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257247499#257247499]
 "There also doesn't seem to be an option to extract a single project from Bamboo and migrate it to another"
fields.summary: Import Export options

fields.description:
Bamboo should show SCM changes for multiple cvs modules? 

I'm using bamboo to build the overnight of a project spread across several cvs modules. The product has a master ant file that calls the builds for the other modules and incorporates all the elements. I'd like to have bamboo watch all the modules for changes and report them.
fields.summary: Bamboo "code Changes" page and Multiple CVS modules

fields.description:
I'm going to be setting up our new Bamboo server soon and that will entail adding 50 or so projects with 3 plans a piece. These will likely only differ in their project name and source URL. It would be nice to automate this.

I don't see anything in the api or plugin module types that would be helpful in this. Am I missing something or is this idea so ludicrous as to be absent. I guess I need a project template configuration file, with a list of parameters and their associated maven pom file counterparts. And then I need a hook in the api to pass this in and create the projects.

This would also be helpful as a maven plugin for furture project creation that could tie into maven's archetype concept.

Thanks!

Originally discussed in http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257247362#257247362
fields.summary: Automate project creation process

fields.description: Currently you have to assign plans to the build queue.  It would be nice to tie a project to a build queue.  This will mean that this build queue can run any plan within that project (instead of having to pick each plan in the project).
fields.summary: Allow for projects to be tied to build queues

fields.description: I created 2 build plans A & B.  I set plan B to be run when A completes successfully.  At a later time, I wanted to remove the dependency between A & B.  I edited plan A, unchecked the dependency and saved the plan.  The dependency is NOT remove.
fields.summary: Unable to remove build plan dependency

fields.description:
When upgrading from 1.0.5 to 1.1, a bunch of .jar files are left behind.

Directory: ...\webapp\WEB-INF\lib

Files:

atlassian-bamboo-api-1.0.5.jar
atlassian-bamboo-build-server-1.0.5.jar
atlassian-bamboo-charts-1.0.5.jar
atlassian-bamboo-core-1.0.5.jar
atlassian-bamboo-language-1.0.5.jar
atlassian-bamboo-license-1.0.5.jar
atlassian-bamboo-migration-1.0.5.jar
atlassian-bamboo-persistence-1.0.5.jar
atlassian-bamboo-plugin-autofavourite-1.0.5.jar
atlassian-bamboo-upgrader-1.0.5.jar
atlassian-bamboo-web-1.0.5.jar

This is easily rectified by deleting the old files and restarting the Bamboo service but I thought I'd write up a bug in case it's a chronic thing that will keep happening with subsequent upgrades.
fields.summary: Upgrade from 1.0.5 to 1.1 leaves old .jar files behind

fields.description:
Had to delete users after moving to LDAP based users.  Manual list a bunch of restrictions, the most critical seems to be:
# You cannot delete a user who has created labels or comments about build results.

So how do you delete a user that has build results?  We ended up deleting all of our build plans.  At first we thought that we could just delete our build results, but the link to do that lead to deleting plans.  How do you delete build results?
fields.summary: Ability to remove local users even when linked to labels comments or favourites

fields.description:
1) Allow graphing to make a graph based on your favourites
2) Put the legend to the right of the graph
3) Allow Control of the legend text. Each Plan has a short key, that could be displayed rather than the Project -Long name combo
4) Allow control over the graph size (There is a lot of empty space)
5) Doesn't help me, but graph aggregate data over all/selected plans in a project
6) Export all data to excel format for external reporting and analysis.
7) Put the legend into a scrollable control
fields.summary: Improvements to the Graph summary in Bamboo

fields.summary: CVS Doesn't Seem to Work

fields.description: i'm about to switch away from polling, but its irritating to hit play on a plan and have to wait because its still got all those other plans to do CVS checks on, even though there isn't a queue displayed. Finish the one you are on and preempt the others to run the one I manually requested.
fields.summary: Bamboo should't loop through all the plans, when building an specific plan.

fields.description: When I create a plan from an existing plan, I don't change very much (CVS Module). I wanted to only go to screen 2 and then immediately finish/save the new plan without going through all the rest of the screens.
fields.summary: Simplify the build cloning process - limit it to 2 steps

fields.description: I dont want the clover HTML report to be an artifact saved with every build, but I would like to be able to see the latest HTML report through the web site. Is this possible
fields.summary: Option to expire artifacts from previous builds

fields.description: When you have many plans and a large screen, its hard to know which plan your hitting build or stop build for. Would be nice if the tool tip told you which one you were about to hit.
fields.summary: Tool tip in the dashboard for the plans.

fields.description: Bulk editing of plans. (e.g. Bamboo can have 50 plans that are almost identical)
fields.summary: Bulk editing of plans

fields.description: In the metadata tab of the build info there is a type in the title "Metatdata"
fields.summary: Metadata title misspelled

fields.description:
Currently to access latest build artifacts you have to go in via the index.html in the latest folder.  You cannot directly link to an artifact (eg you can  type /download/latest/myArtifacts/myfile in the browser)

Chris wrote a patch to do this by analysing the file system (attached see method: checkForLatestDataPath)

This should probably be done by the URL re-write functionality.
fields.summary: Be able to access 'latest' build artifacts from anywhere

fields.description: Looking at AnthillPro, they have the concept of a quite period on commits.  User sets a value (say 5 minutes) for the quiet period.  Build is triggered when there are commits AND a quiet period of time has passed with NO commits.  This allows for a bunch of commits to be done before build is kicked of.  For instance, 2 or more developers coordinating their commits.  Also covers the case when a single developer "forgets" submitting something and needs to correct it quickly.
fields.summary: Commit quiet period

fields.description:
Please consider offering an integration with the Amazon EC2 service (http://www.amazon.com/gp/browse.html?node=201590011), for running the builders or the complete application on the Amazon cloud.

This can save customers the cost of dedicated servers, & also enable concurrent builds. (Compare also the TeamCity offerings - distributed build agents.)

Security can be an issue, but many organization allow secured remote version control clients.
fields.summary: Run builders on Amazon cloud

fields.description: A remote API to retrieve a build result.
fields.summary: Remote API to retrieve full Build Results Summary

fields.description:
One common method of putting a proxy-server in front of a Java appserver is to use mod_proxy.  However, when using mod_proxy the connecting IP address is proxying host (often 127.0.0.1), which breaks triggers as the connecting host won't match the repository host.  Note that this will also apply where other forms or proxies (load-balancers, client caching proxies) are in place.

One option is to inspect the headers for the 'X-Forwarded-For:' header, which contains the IP of the original connecting host.  The longer term (probably correct) option is to use HTTP-basic auth instead of IP filtering.
fields.summary: Bamboo doesn't recognise repository address when fronted by a proxy server

fields.summary: Internal Server Error when doing a clean install

fields.description:
I would like to get im on every build, and only get emails on failures, for example. But right now I cannot configure them separately.
Some people need to see every build, others only failures. An I second the vote for sending messages to the submitters that brought down a build.
fields.summary: Ability to configure email and IM notifications separately

fields.description:
Build numbers 1,2,3,... etc, from Bamboo are not particularly meaningful. Would appreciate a way to program the build label, to correlate it with the change numbers in perforce.

So if I submit a change, 161174, and it triggers a build, I will know from the Bamboo notification that my change is included in the build.
fields.summary: Build Number should be configurable (e.g. to track Perforce Change Numbers)

fields.description:
I've created a plan that hasn't yet been built, and was browsing the tabs to see what information was available.  The 'Completed Builds' tab has the following text on it:
    "Bamboo builds everything whenever the Subversion source code repository changes."

...but the build strategy for plan for my project is "Manual builds only".
fields.summary: Text on 'Completed Builds' page doesn't match plan build strategy.

fields.description:
We are finding that the bamboo webapp is painfully slow to load any pages; for instance, the 'all plans' list typically takes about 45s to load. We have about 50 build plans, so this is almost a second per plan! Bamboo is running on a box with a hyperthreaded 3GHz processor and 2GB ram (which isn't doing much else) - so we really would hope to see better performance than this.

Is there anything we can do to help improve this?
fields.summary: Dashboard very slow

fields.description:
One of the points made with Bamboo is the ability to use the CI process to control things other that the standard *build* stuff like backups and publishing to web sites, etc...  This makes Bamboo more valuable to manage and control these other processes in a consistent way with all the metrics and notification support that Bamboo provides.  However, many of those processes are schedule based and *not* based on repository changes.  Specifically, there is no need to specify a repository at all.  The request is to provide an option to specify repository of *none* or similar way to specify in a build plan that the repository checkout phase is not required.  The build in this case is just a script.  
I guess the workaround with current bamboo is configure some unimportant repository checkout
fields.summary: Non-repository based builds

fields.description:
Product started and configured ok.  However, on restart, it failed to find the database.  Looking at the logs, the database file reference was not correct.  The reason was:
Home directory setting had a ending blank in the directory name.  This was transferred into the bamboo.cfg.xml so that a resulting restart failed to find the database.  Attached is the resulting file.  Notice the extra blank in *c:/bamboo-data /database/defaultdb*

Easily corrected by editing the config file and restarting.
fields.summary: Bamboo fails to restart successfully due to bad database reference

fields.description: It would be very useful if Bamboo picked up errors from javac (in ant, maven, etc..) and showed them on the "build failed" summary page in a place as promiment as the test failures.
fields.summary: Bamboo should pickup errors from javac (in ant, maven, etc..) and showed them on the "build failed" summary page

fields.description:
When someone checks in a changelist with multiple lines in the comment, Bamboo parses out the first line as the change comment, but the rest of the lines end up in the bulleted list of individual file changes, like this:

{noformat}
This build was the result of the following change:

    * Matthew Janulewicz
      Matthew Janulewicz

      Adding a space to try to trigger a build, which should trigger an integration between Bamboo and Jira (I hope.)
          o Jobs fixed ... (version )
          o SD-3004 on 2007/04/26 by matthewja *closed* (version )
          o Testing Bamboo/Jira integration. Please ignore this. (version )
          o Affected files ... (version )
          o ... //DotNet/main/Source/DataAccess/latest/AssemblyInfo.vb (version 2)
{noformat}

Note that the inclusion of jobs also wreaks havoc on the change description.

An interesting (and frustrating, until I figured it out) side-effect of this is that the Bamboo<->Jira integration will not work unless the checkin comment includes the Jira issue ID on the first line.

It might be extra-neato if the Changes tab included the changelist(s) involved, not just the individual files. Plus, parsed out the comments correcty. :)
fields.summary: Multiline Perforce submit comments are incorrectly parsed as file changes

fields.description:
There seems to be a pattern with changes that can not get a change log.

If the build is triggered and placed in a queue for building, and meanwhile another build is taking a long time in that queue, then changes made to the code during that time period will not retrieve changelogs.

In the following scenario:
 LW-NIGHTLY - runs for approximately 2.5 hours, scheduled build
 LW-COMPONENTS - runs for approximately 15 minutes, polling build

LW-NIGHTLY is triggered to run.  Meanwhile, a change (CHANGE-A) happens that would cause LW-COMPONENTS to build, so it queues up a build.  CHANGE-A is correctly recognized.  After LW-COMPONENTS is queued, another change happens that would cause another build (CHANGE-B).  When LW-NIGHTLY finishes, LW-COMPONENTS does its initially queued build (containing only CHANGE-A).  Then it performs a cvs update, sees a file changed, and attempts to get a changelog.  The changelog retrieval for CHANGE-B seems to be using an incorrect timestamp (that of the time the prior build began, not the time the prior build was queued), so any changes that happen between queue time and build time are lost.
fields.summary: Changes Made While Build is In Queue Don't Get Change Logs

fields.description: The documentation says Perforce does not support build triggers to kick off a build on a commit.  Looking at the perforce documentation, it appears that there is a change-commit trigger that can do the appropriate thing.  http://perforce.com/perforce/doc.062/manuals/p4sag/06_scripting.html#1061665
fields.summary: Bamboo should accept repository triggers for Perforce builds

fields.description: What a rude introduction to the product!   Creating a new plan.  Go through a few panels.  Its validating stuff on the way, so there are errors that take time to resolve (like my perforce client that needs to be modified).  Finally got everything set correctly.  Bang - timeout - all data is lost!  There is no ability to save data along the way.  There is no ability to turn off the validation so you can get to the save button on the last page.  If you designed it to work this way, then its a design bug.
fields.summary: Create plan input lost on timeout

fields.description: I'm mulling over redoing our project heirarchy and grouping things a little more logically, and realize that being able to group projects in Bamboo would be brilliant. It's already stellar that each project can contain multiple build plans. Having project groups (a la Jira) would make my OCD squeal. Any chance of this?
fields.summary: Bamboo should be able to group projects

fields.description: It would be nice if we could just export and import only the configuration of the plans and not all the associated build data.
fields.summary: Ability to export/import just the configuration, not the data

fields.description:
My build will run ok from the command prompt but fails test when run from Bamboo.  Bamboo fails to pass the environment variables to Maven2 needed to run tests.

Commands to run from command prompt:
  cd /home/jboss/bamboo/xml-data/build-dir/LUM-JAR/common/lum
  export JAVA_HOME=/usr/java/jdk1.5.0_10 
  /opt/maven/current2/bin/mvn -Denv=dev -Dschema=dpir -Ddatabase.password=dpir clean package
These commands perform the build sucessfully.

Attached are the test log file (BuildTestLog.txt) and the Bamboo build log (BambooBuildLog.txt)

Is an update of my Bamboo installation from 1.0.1 to 1.0.5 just a matter of replacing the war file?  I am just using the HSQL db for now.
fields.summary: JVM parameters not getting set

fields.description:
There are some ways for an author to be falsely 'accused' of breaking a build:
- failures due to environmental changes: DB changes for DB Unit tests, JVM crash, Maven cannot remove a folder, ...
- another author also has checked in failing code

When this happens, the statistic for this author get screwed up. If it happens quite a lot, the authors statistics are useless. This is too bad, since I think it motivates developers to check in often, and to assure the tests keep running.

I would very much like to see a feature in bamboo that allows an administrator to clear an author from the 'blame' of a failed build, to make the statistics reliable again.
fields.summary: Implement possibility to manually change responsibility for failed build

fields.description: Bamboo to support other IM protocols -  SIMPLE, MSN, YAHOO, AIM/ICQ, Groupwise and etc
fields.summary: IM support for non-jabber based protocols

fields.description: At the Spring CI instance, we work against multiple repositories, SF, java.net , etc.  For some of our users, each system has it's own username that is different.  We'd like to be able to multiselect from the list of repository aliases for each user to to allow for this case.
fields.summary: All multiple repository aliases
